keyTakeAways: A man who sexually assaulted a college student in 2013 was sentenced to two to four years in prison after being extradited from France, highlighting long-standing challenges in prosecuting campus sexual assault cases.

The victim, Shannon Keeler, waited over a decade to pursue charges due to lack of prosecution and destroyed forensic evidence, underscoring systemic failures in how campus sexual violence is addressed.
Cleary’s guilty plea, remorse, and mental health history influenced the judge’s decision to impose a sentence below state guidelines, reflecting a balance between accountability and rehabilitation.
The Facebook message sent by Cleary in 2019 re-activated the case and led to renewed legal action, showing how digital communication can serve as a catalyst in long-overdue justice.
The case illustrates the broader issue of how institutions fail to protect victims of sexual assault, especially on college campuses, and the emotional toll it takes on survivors.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A man named Ian Cleary, who sexually assaulted a woman at Gettysburg College in 2013, was sentenced to two to four years in prison on October 20, 2025. After being extradited from France in 2024 following a vagrancy arrest, Cleary faced prosecution nearly 12 years after the assault. The case gained momentum in 2019 when Cleary sent a Facebook message saying 'So I raped you,' prompting Keeler, the victim, to renew her efforts with authorities. Despite years of inaction, lack of prosecution, and destruction of forensic evidence, Keeler pursued charges after public advocacy through an Associated Press story in 2021. The judge, Senior Judge Kevin Hess, sentenced Cleary below state guidelines due to his guilty plea, remorse, and history of mental illness. The case reflects broader systemic failures in campus sexual assault prosecutions, where victims face long delays, emotional trauma, and lack of support from institutions.
title: Man Sentenced for 2013 College Sexual Assault After 12-Year Delay
